Thorough risk assessments will be carried out and cleansing stations will be implemented on site."

title: coronavirus-people-scotland-can-take-part-covid-19-vaccine-trial
story: PEOPLE in Scotland are being encouraged to take part in coronavirus vaccine trials.Speaking at the Scottish Governments daily briefing yesterday,Deputy chief medical officer Nicola Steedman asked members of the public to consider whether they could volunteer during the testing phase of the drug.Last week, findings from the early phases of a vaccine being created by Oxford University were published, with Ms Steedman saying the vaccine was both safe and created a ldquogood response in the more than  test subjects.She added: ldquoItrsquos still early days, but itrsquos definitely good news.Ms Steedman said: ldquoScience and research has never been more important than it is now.How can I help Larger-scale trials will be required to ensure that vaccines can be rigorously tested in the coming months and Ms Steedman has said a registry has been set up across the UK for people to sign up to be a part of Covid- trials.Ms Steedman said, adding: ldquoPlease do visit the online siteyou can and think about whether you, like so many others, can volunteer to help with vaccine trials.Online sign-up can be found at www.nhs.uk researchcontactIf you are interested in volunteering for #COVIDvaccine studies, you can register and find out more at https:t.co ZYZzEbIhttps:t.co WhQfkZSsmdash Nicola SturgeonJuly , What  was said at the briefing The First Minister confirmedanother four positive cases of the virusin Scotland, bringing the total to ,.No deaths have been recorded in the last  hours, meaning the total number of fatalities remains at .But NicolaSturgeon said the Scottish Government is likely to adopt a ldquocautious approach to lockdown easing when its planned review takes place on Thursday.She warned there is a ldquoworrying resurgence of Covid cases globally and stressed the hospitality sector in Scotland must ensure it is adhering to guidelines put in place.

title: peebles-shop-owner-irene-says-fond-farewell-customers
story: AFTER nearly four decades in business, Peebles shop owner Irene Ruffell is saying a fond farewell to staff and customers.Irene has spent more than half of her le serving the town after she, and late husband Stuart, opened up their Spar grocery store in Rosetta Road in .Three years later they opened the Glen Road branch.And they successfully ran both shops before selling the Rosetta Road store in .Stuart died in , and Irene credits her loyal staff who she calls her ldquofriends for comforting her through this dficult time in her le.Recalling some of their fond and funny memories over the years, Irene and Stuart did more for their customers than bag groceries.Irene said: ldquoMany years ago when we were at Rosetta Road we had to help a wee old lady. The clip to the suspender belt of her stockings snapped."Luckily Irene managed to save the pensionerrsquos modesty by fashioning together a clip to fix the wardrobe mal.ldquoOn another occasion we fixed a hearing aid for an elderly man who came into the shop. All part of the service! she joked.The couple loved helping their customers, and on many occasions, when elderly residents wondered into the shop from Dunwhinny Care Home, they would personally walk them back to the nursing home complex.Irene added: ldquoSome of our older customers will simply pop in for a wee chat when they were feeling lonely and it was nice to be there for them all of these years."Asked what she plans to do in her retirement, Irene said: ldquoAbsolutely nothing ndash for a while anyway! But Irsquom sure Irsquoll be called upon for babysitting duties as I have two grandchildren and another on the way.The -year-old had planned to jet off on holiday with family to celebrate her retirement, but COVID- meant they had to cancel their plans.As for a socially distanced retirement celebration, Irene said: ldquoIrsquove nothing planned. Irsquoll just slip out of the door quietly I think.Irene is passing the shop keys to Adam Purves Galashiels Ltd on Wednesday, August .As she closes the shop door and opens one to a new chapter in her le, we asked Irene how she feels about saying farewell.She said: ldquoI feel quite emotional. There will definitely be a tear in my eye as my memories and my le with Stuart are in that shop. But itrsquos time, time to say goodbye and thank you to everyone for their custom and friendship over the last  years.

title: bringing-services-back-normal-priority-council-leader
story: COUNCIL leader Shona Haslam says her number one priority over the coming weeks will be to bring services back to normality.Ahead of herto the hot seat, the Conservative member for Tweeddale East also said ldquoeducation and getting the kids back to school safely will be an immediate goal.And she is concerned job losses recently announced in the region are ldquojust the beginning.In March, councillors voted to hand decision-making responsibilities to the councilrsquos chief executive, Tracey Logan.But councillor Haslam isdue to regain control tomorrow .Councillor Haslam, who lives in Peebles, said: ldquoDuring COVID, like many councils across Scotland, we delegated powers to the chief executive.ldquoThis was necessary to allow officers to make the very swt decisions that they were required to take as well as dealing with the fact that we could not meet as a council.ldquoThe decisions taken during this time were mainly all COVID response-related and councillors were consulted every step of the way.ldquoHowever, with things starting toto this lsquonew normalrsquo we felt it was time to bring decision making powers back to the full council.ldquoWe have also now put in place all of the requirements to allow the council to meet virtually and for the public to view our meetings which means we can do a lot more online now.When asked about her administrationrsquos immediate priorities, councillorHaslam said: ldquoWhile our working practices are starting to develop in this new situation we find ourselves in the COVID recovery and response continues for the council.ldquoOver the summer we are still providing free school meals to many children, supporting those who are shielding, and trying to bring services back within the new government guidelines of social distancing.ldquoThis will take time and I want to thank everyone for their understanding in this. We have not been able to do many of the things that the council normally does like, we have not been allowed to cut grass with normal mowers, for just one example.ldquoOpening our recycling centres has required additional staff, collecting bins has required additional vehicles and staff, all of these things have had a massive impact.ldquoSo our number one priority over the coming weeks is to bring council services as back to normal as possible.ldquoEducation and getting the kids back to school safely on August  is our immediate priority. The government does not announce the guidance on this until July  so we are working to very tight timescales.When asked about her hopes for the Borders in the coming year, councillorHaslam said: ldquoA sense of normality would be nice, but that seems far away at the moment.ldquoWe have to do some work to understand exactly what sections of our communities are going to be most badly affected over the next year and make sure that we have the support mechanisms in place to ensure that they are looked after.ldquoI am fearful for the economy of the Borders, we have seen lots of businesses announce potential job losses over the last three months and I do worry that this is just the beginning.ldquoWe have to make sure that all of the economic initiatives that we have like the Borderlands Growth Deal and the South of Scotland Enterprise Agency are working in the right ways in the right places to ensure that we are creating new jobs and building the economy.

title: gala-cricket-club-make-difference-fundraiser
story: GALA Cricket Club have raised pound for charity through their lsquok in Mayrsquo challenge.With the season postponed by the coronavirus pandemic, players, members and supporters decided to stay active by walking, cycling or jogging , kilometres.And the Meigle Park club smashed their pound target for NHS Bordersrsquo official charitywhile completing more than ,km.The organisation supports patients across the region, providing the lsquoadded extrasrsquo which are not offered by the health board.One of the Gala CC organisers, Ross Patterson, said: ldquoWe are delighted with the final total of kilometres travelled and money raised for The Dference and thank everyone who supported K in May in any way.ldquoThis has been a dficult time for everyone but the club is pleased to be able to give something back to the NHS for the unbelievable service they have provided during this most challenging of times.Gala Cricket Club are now back training under strict guidelines, and are expected to play a number of games against Borders clubs next month, subject to Scottish Government and CricketScotland approval. Anyone interested in becoming involved in the club should visit www.galacricketclub or go to the social media channels.

title: sbc-announces-measures-schools-reopening
story: SCOTTISH Borders Councilhas revealed what measures will likely be in place once schools can reopen on August .The range of new measures will include increased handwashing and sanitising throughout schools and clear signage about these rules.SBC chief executive, Tracey Logan, said: "We donrsquot know how long some of these arrangements will be required as this all depends on ongoing scientic and health advice."Although schooldays will run as usual, there is the chance for early starts or finishes for P and S students who are transitioning into their new schools.Parents and carers of pupils at Jedburgh Grammar will receive guidance directly from SBC as separate arrangements are in place - in line with normal procedures for the opening of a new school.Following from Scottish Government advice, schoolchildren will not have to social distance in school and face coverings are not required.However, the local authority has claried that any pupil or members of their family exhibiting COVID- symptoms are not to attend school.School transport will also operate as normal from August , with no distancing or face covering measures in place.Parents and carers will receive further guidance on school transport on Monday, August .In her full statement, Ms Logan said: "We have been working on these plans for some time now and can reassure parents, pupils and staff that everything will be in place to make all our Early Years settings and schools as safe as possible."This includes signicantly enhanced cleaning programmes, staggered break and lunch times for pupils where required and timetable arrangements to minimise pupil movements between classrooms in secondary schools. In line with current guidance, split and shared placements will not take place."We donrsquot know how long some of these arrangements will be required as this all depends on ongoing scientic and health advice. However, we will continually review them to make sure that we are providing the best possible educational opportunities for all our young people whilst meeting the requirements set out in the Scottish Governmentrsquos guidance."We understand that parents and carers will have a iety of questions and further information and guidance will be published from Monday  August."It is vital to emphasise that this will not be ato lsquonormalrsquo and all schools will use the first week as an opportunity to provide a smooth transition to the new arrangements."We also recognise that our new P and S pupils have not had the normal transitional opportunities ahead of the new school year due to COVID-, so our schools will be doing all they can to support them and parents in the initial week to make the transition as smooth as possible."Updates will be available on the council website at: www.scotborders.gov.uk schoolreopening

title: peebles-theatre-founding-member-celebrates-100th-birthday
story: A FOUNDING member of the Eastgate Theatre has celebrated her th birthday.Margaret Jamieson marked becoming a centenarian with a glass of bubbly and a slice of cake at Peebles Care Home on Sunday.As well as receiving well wishes from local friends and family, she also received her telegram from the Queen, alongside birthday messages from former colleagues and distanced friends.ldquoI canrsquot believe I reached , said Ms Jamieson, ldquohow did it happen Ms Jamieson was born in Edinburgh on July , , and was the eldest of five children.She has been heralded as a ldquovery independent lady, having travelled around the world, visiting Japan, Indonesia, Yemen, Canada, and numerous other far-off locations.This newspaperasked Ms Jamieson to look back on her  years, and to pinpoint some of her fondest memories, as well as others which stick out in the mind.She said: ldquo[There are] So many.ldquoBeing in North Berwick when my mother gave birth to her first set of twins: my mother and father went on holiday with one child and came back with three!ldquoMy time as a pupil at James Gillespiersquos, walking home with Muriel Spark and being head girl.ldquoGoing to Germany immediately after the Second World War where I saw terrible poverty and just how terrible the war had been for the German people.ldquoMy time as principal at IM Marsh College in Liverpool.ldquoMy travels to all parts of the world. I particularly remember being in Iran where I had to wear a full robe ndash so many women wanted to come up and speak to me in English. Iran is a much misunderstood country.ldquoBuilding my house in Peebles ndash or rather overseeing it. I loved the views over Peebles, the hills, the town.ldquoI couldnrsquot have picked a better place to retire to.ldquoMy only regret is not being physically able to get out and about as much as I used to.Her career, beginning as a PE teacher in Liverpool, spanned decades and even took her to post-war Germany to teach army children in .Then, in , she was elected as college principal at the IM Marsh College Liverpool ndash a position which she remained in until .She was also one of the founding members of the Eastgate Theatre, as the arts hold a special place in her heart.ldquoIt was very important to create the Eastgate Theatre, Ms Jamieson said.ldquoWe are so near Edinburgh but not everyone can go there to the theatres and concert halls.ldquoHere, being near Edinburgh and in a wonderful place, we can attract acts who also go to Edinburgh. I still go to concerts with a carer and often the acts come here to the care home.Any birthday under lockdown regulations would be odd, but to mark  years in the midst of the coronavirus pandemic is odder still.At her celebration on Sunday, due to restrictions, family members who could visit did so from Tweed Green and looked on as she read her royal telegram.ldquoIt was odd, she added. ldquoI wanted to see my family but they couldnrsquot come in to see me.ldquoThey had to stand out in the street but it was still wonderful they could be there.When asked what final piece of advice she would give to readers on how to lead a happy and long le, Ms Jamieson said: ldquoKeep fit and healthy and donrsquot put off doing tomorrow what you could do today.

title: scotlands-schools-reopening-august-11-rules-parents-kids-must-know
story: Pupils will be back in classes full-time by mid-August, Nicola Sturgeon has announced.The First Minister said schools can reopen from August  but some local authorities may chose to have a in consistent groups throughout the school day wherever possible.Adults within the school are expected to maintain m physical distancing between other adults and children young people wherever coverings, but adults should.Anyone travelling to school on public transport must follow the public transport guidance on face coverings and distancing.,params: .pushHygiene:The Scottish Government belongings are brought into school.Enhanced hygiene measures must be practiced, including:Extra time for pupils and staff to clean their hands with soap and warm running water or sanisiser when: they title: scotlands-lockdown-phase-3-seven-key-dates-know-measures-eased
story: NICOLA Sturgeon yesterday set out key indicitive dates for further changes to lockdown rules in Scotland.Giving her three-weekly update to the Scottish Parliament, the First Minister confirmed that we would not be moving into Phase  of the route-map out of lockdown.The priority remains keeping the coronavirus prevalence low to get pupils back to school safely in August, with minimal changes to anything  in the coming weeks.She said that the Scottish Government estimates about  people in Scotland currently have Covid-. Last week that estimation was about .The R number is also still below one, she said.During the briefing she did, however, outline a series of indicitive dartes for further changes to rules - provided there is no sustained rise in the virus.Here we outline those seven dates:From August :The Scottish Government will pause the advice for peoples shielding in Scotland.From Saturday, they will follow the same guidance as the general population.But the First Minister has encouraged them to be especially carefully during their day-to-day lives.Today First Minister @NicolaSturgeonconfirmed that Scotlands schools will re-open full-time from  August, with enhanced public health measures in place and additional funding provided to support a safe .Read more ## title: five-borders-communities-set-ultra-fast-broadband
story: FIVE communities in the Borders are to get new ultra-fast broadband.Galashiels, Tweedbank, Selkirk, Peebles and Hawick are among  places to benefit from the new poundbillion plan by Telecoms company Openreach.Borders MP John Lamont welcomed the news.He said: ldquoPoor broadband and mobile signal is one of the most common causes of complaints in the Borders."This has only intensied due to more and more people working from home over the last few months."Thatrsquos why I am delighted that Openreach is investing in better broadband across towns in Selkirkshire and Roxburghshire."Better broadband really makes a dference to peoplersquos lives for work and for recreation."Work is expected to get under way in many of the announced locations within the next - months.But due to the size of the build, some places will see work continue into .Clive Selley, chief executive of Openreach, said: ldquoThis year wersquove all seen the importance of having a decent broadband connection, and at Openreach wersquore convinced that full fibre technology can underpin the UKrsquos economic recovery."Wersquore determined to find inventive engineering solutions and effective partnership funding models to reduce costs and enable us to connect as many communities as possible across the UK without public subsidy."Openreach is leading the charge to help government achieve its target of making gigabit capable networks available nationwide by .ldquoWe hope that by publishing our own plans, we can help ensure that taxpayers only fund connections in communities that really need public support.

title: 15-things-weekend-scotland-lockdown-eases
story: Scotland is slowlybeginning to open back up.And as were all getting used to like taking on its new normal, we pulled together a list ofthings to do this weekend to get you out of the house.Here are the top  things to do this weekend:VISIT A CASTLE ndash CAERLAVEROCK CASTLEWhile the actual castle is currently closed, the grounds and green spaces of Caerlaverock Castle are now open for free as one of Scottish Tourismrsquosopen-air sites. The castlersquos wide moat, towered gatehouse and battlements make it look like something straight out of a fairytale.Caerlaverock CastleIn fact, the castle has been a popular filming location, featuring in films such as the Decoy Bride starring David Tenant. Gaze up at the formidable red sandstone defensive walls, unique in Britain for the triangular shape, and take in a piece of Scottish history.Caerlaverock Castle, Glencaple, Dumfries, DG RU.  .THE REAL MARY KINGrsquoS CLOSEThe Royal Mary Kingrsquos Close in Edinburgh opened back up to the public last Saturday. Located underneaththe Royal Mile, this five-star attraction features uniquely preserved th-century streets and has spent lockdown redesigning its tours to ensure the safety of staff and visitors alike ndash including preparing some exciting new tour features.The tours will run at % capacity and staff will be wearing masks and gloves where possible, maintaining a social distance at all times. The attraction has been given ldquoGood to Go status by VisitScotland, so visitors can be sure their safety is a priority. Delve into Edinburghrsquos murky history and explore places once inhabited by some of the cityrsquos most influential people.The Real Mary King Close, Warristonrsquos Close,  High Street, Edinburgh, EH PG. Tours run from am-.pm. Tickets from pound, can be booked onlineSLOANSPut down the takeaway menus and get yourself out for a good, old-fashioned sit-down, pub meal. Since  Sloans has been serving thirsty Glaswegians and this week they finally reopened their doors to the public.With a fully heated and covered outdoor courtyard, book yourself a spot outside. Or,itrsquos a little chilly and you want to stay inside, it has plenty of indoor seating on offer.Like everywhere, Sloans has made some important changes to ensure the safety of customers and employees alike, including social distancing, online bookings and contactless payments only, as well as regular cleaning and hand-sanitiser stations throughout the pub.Sloans,  Argyll Arcade,  Argyll Street, Glasgow, G BG. Monday-Sunday, noon-pm.   .THE SAINT BEER GARDENOne of the lesser known spots in St Andrews, The Saintrsquos beer garden is the perfect place to relax with a pint in the fresh air. After reopening its doors earlier this month, the Saint has put several measures in place to ensure the safety of staff and customers.These include temperature checks on arrival, as well as submitting your details for contact tracing. Booking in advance is mandatory and tables are limited to six people. But donrsquot worry ndash yoursquoll still have ample time to enjoy your drinks as you have your reservation for just less than two hours. Therersquos plenty of space to enjoy a relaxing drink not too far away from the hustle and bustle of the town centre.The Saint Bar  Kitchen,  South Street, St Andrews, KY EG.Monday-Sunday -pm.  .THE SCOTTISH GALLERYHead to the Scottish Gallery this weekend for your artistic fix! The gallery reopenedearlier this month and visitors can call or email the gallery to plan their visit ahead of time.Therersquos a host of exhibitions on show this month including Davy Brown at  ndash Brownrsquos th birthday exhibition with the galleryndash showcasing his still le and landscape painting.As well as The Edinburgh School exhibition, featuring pieces from artists associated with the Edinburgh College of Art after the First World War.The Scottish Gallery,  Dundas Street, Edinburgh, EH HZ. Tuesday-Friday am-pm and Saturday am-pm .HIGHLAND FOLK MUSEUMIf yoursquore looking for something educational to do in the north of Scotland in the coming weeks then the Highland Folk Museum is the place to go. Theyrsquore reopening on Wednesday and will be open every Wednesday through to Sunday, with visitors needing to pre-book their visit online.The collections on display at the museum mainly reflect the social and rural way of le in the Scottish Highlands from the s all the way through to the mid-s. Some of the collections include the Agricultural Collectionand the Domestic Collection with items ranging from cooking material through heating, lighting and laundry to traditional house fittings and furniture, along with many other collections, giving you ample opportunity to learn about all aspects of the history of the Scottish Highlands.Highland Folk Museum, Kingussie Road, Newtonmore, PH AY. Wednesday-Sunday .am-pm .  .TAKE A SCENIC DRIVE ndash ABERFOYLE TO CALLANDERFor a fun activity that doesnrsquot even involve getting out of the car, this scenic drive from Aberfoyle to Callander, via the Three Lochs Forest, is a perfect weekend activity.On this quiet forest road you can venture through the woodlands of the Queen Elizabeth Forest Park, which stretches almost eight miles, taking you past three enchanting lochs ndash Lochan Reoidhte, Loch Drunkie and Loch Achray.The drive only takes about an hour and  minutes but there are several car parks on the drive, as well as picnic areas and some short trailsyou fancy a walk to stretch your legs.,params: .pushAccess the entrance to the Three Lochs Forest Drive from the A just north of Aberfoyle . Departure point: Aberfoyle.CHECK OUT A FARMERSrsquo MARKET ndash LEITH MARKETAlthough farmersrsquo markets ed this month, they look very dferent, but are still a great day out. All traders will be at least two metres away from one another and there will be no hot food .Therersquos also no craft stalls at the moment, but therersquos plenty of fresh food for visitors to browse and purchase. Social distancing measures are being enforced and all staff are wearing masks.Leith Market Dock Place, EH LU.Open every Saturday from am-pm.HAVE A PICNIC AT ROWARDENNANThis tranquil spot on the banks of Loch Lomond is the perfect place for a summerrsquos day picnic. Take in the views of the loch and even go for a paddle at Rowardennan before you eat.Afterwards, the Ben Lomond Memorial Trail is a short, easy walk that ends at the Ben Lomond Memorial Park, which features the award-winning sculpture from artist Doug Cocker framing the peak of Ben Lomond.G AR is the nearest postcode ndash follow the signs from Drymen.CAMP AT HORGABOST CAMPSITENestled away at the south of Harris is the remote Horgabost Campsite, perfect for a weekend staycation.The views here stretch out over the water, interrupted only by the gentle rise of Taransay Island. Its remoteness makes it the perfect place to stargaze. And, being so far north, you may be able to catch a glimpse of the Northern Lights.Horgabost, Isle of Harris, Hebrides, HS HR.  .GRAB SOME AFTERNOON TEA AT THE WILLOW TEA ROOMSInspired by the works of Charles Rennie Mackintosh, the Willow Tea Rooms in Glasgow are modelled after Kate Cranstonrsquos Ingram Street Tea Rooms from the early-s and is the perfect place to indulge in some afternoon tea in style.Although booking is not mandatory, customers are encouraged to book in advanceto guarantee a table, minimise queues and prevent congestion at the entrance to the Willow. They will also be serving a reduced menu for the first few weeks while they get to grips with this new way of dining ndash but itjust gives you an opportunity to try something new!Buchanan Street, Glasgow, G HF Mon-Fri am-pm Sat am-.pm Sun am-.pm.   .VISIT A BOTANICAL GARDEN ndash DAWYCK BOTANIC GARDENDawyck Botanic Garden is a five-star garden, known for its seasonaldisplays of flowers such as snowdrops, bluebells, rhododendrons andazaleas. Surrounded by the hills of the Scottish Borders, Dawyck has an almost continental feel to its climate during the summer months allowing plants from places including China, Nepal, Japan and North America to thrive.Take a look at some of the plants on display, including Heritage Trees and blue poppies. The cafes are also open, offering a range of refreshments to take away that you can enjoy in the gardens.Dawyck Botanic Gardens, Stobo, Scottish Borders, EH JU. Open daily from am-pm. Tickets from pound. HAVE A BEACH DAY ndash ROSEISLE BEACHTrees growing down to the waterrsquos edge is not a common sight among Scotlandrsquos beaches, but trees andsand together can be found on the beach at Roseisle in Moray near Elgin. In the woodlands beside the beach, there are plenty of walks and trails to take on.Beside the sea, there are interesting historical objects, such as pillboxes and concrete blocks dating back to the Second World War. On the horizon, you can gaze upon the clfs surrounding Cromarty Firth and the long line of northern hills.Kinloss, Forres, Morayshire, IV UB.FLY A KITE ndash PETTYCUR BAYLockdown has been the perfect timeto learn new skills. If you havenrsquot already, why not make one of themkite flying ndash the ideal socially distanced activity. And Pettycur Bay in Feis a great spot to learn to kite fly.When the tide is out, therersquos a mile-and-a-half of solid beach to work with. Although kite surfers also use the beach, youcan easily kite-fly alongside. However, be careful as when the tide is in there is no beach.Pettycur Bay, Burntisland KY SB.TAKE A TRIP TO THE ZOO ndash EDINBURGH ZOOA family favourite day out, trips to the zoo are back! Edinburgh Zoohas reopened with a wide range of safety measures in place to protect visitors and staff alike, including new one-way routes and wearing face coverings in indoor areas.Visitors also must book a time slot in advance to ensure everything runs as smoothly as possible. Almost all of their indoor animal areas are open but keeper talks and public animal feeds have been postponed until further notice.Edinburgh Zoo,  Corstorphine Road, Corstorphine, Edinburgh EH TSTickets from pound. Open daily from am-pm.   .

title: eat-help-out-scotland----taking-part-half-price-scheme
story: RESIDENTS across Scotlandwill tomorrow beable to claim discounts at scores of restaurants andfoodestablishments.From August  to August ,onMondays, Tuesdays and Wednesdays, restaurantsparticipating in the UK Governments Eat Out to Help Out scheme will offer  per cent offfoodand non-alcoholic drinks up to a total value of pound per person.Alcoholic drinks and service charges are excluded from the offer.The initiative, launched by Chancellor Rishi Sunak, is encouraging peopleto support the hospitality industry by getting back to having meals out ascoronaviruslockdown measures are eased.Restaurants are offering % off foodYou donrsquot need a voucher to use the scheme and you can use it at the same time as other offers and discounts. title: pandemic-toughest-challenging-period-councils-history
story: THE coronavirus pandemic has been "without doubt the toughest and most challenging" period Scottish Borders Council has ever had to face, according to its leader.At a virtual meeting of the council on Thursday, elected members voted to take back emergency powers from the chief executive, Tracey Logan and hand them to Tweeddale East councillor Shona Haslam.Speaking at the meeting, councillor Haslam said: ldquoThe last five months have been, without doubt, the toughest and most challenging that this council has ever had to face.ldquoThe pressures on our staff and resources have been immense, the impact will be felt for years and will not be fully known for some time.ldquoThroughout this pandemic the officers of this council have had to take very swt decisions and react quickly to government guidance and I want to thank them for the efforts that they have made to fully consult with councillors all the way along.ldquoI also want to thank councillor Stuart Bell who has worked collegiately with myself throughout this situation to ensure that all councillors have felt fully engaged in any decisions that have been made.ldquoI want to thank the officers, staff and partners of the council for their incredible work over the last five months to respond to this ever changing situation that we have found ourselves in.ldquoBut I also want to particularly mention all of the incredible community volunteers, resilient community groups and COVID- response groups who have done so much in our community.ldquoThe level of community engagement and co-working with council services has been amazing to see and this is something that we must hold onto, and learn from for the future.Fellow Tweeddale East councillor Stuart Bell, who leads the main SNP opposition at the council, said: ldquoAs I said in March when these emergency powers were agreed, lsquoboldmeasures are needed to stop this pandemic overwhelming our way of lersquo.ldquoBold measures were taken, and now, the degree of normality that allows full-education to restart in our schools is the right point to resume normalcouncil business, and switch off the emergency provisions.ldquoBut I remind colleagues that two of the three concerns I expressed in Marchare still relevant.ldquoWhilst there is now a mechanism to continue making planning decisions,there remains a backlog of deferred decisions, and the financial consequencesof the lockdown are signicant and growing ndash whilst the same problem isfacing other local authorities, that doesnrsquot make it easier to address.ldquoI tried to give a message of hope in March and whilst there is more to hopefor there is now no less uncertainty.ldquoIt is estimated that only five per cent of the Scottish population has actually had COVID- which means that the best that almost all of us can hope, is that we maypersonally not be susceptible to a devastating infection that is all around us.ldquoThat is why in thanking the council staff for their application and flexibility, andalso thanking the general public for their forbearance, I particularly want tothank the hundreds of ordinary, neighbourly folk who have been supportinglocal community resilience.

title: young-borders-entrepreneurs-taking-business-hands
story: YOUNG entrepreneurs from across the Borders are emerging after lockdown.With studies predicting a steep rise in youth unemployment this year, some young people are taking matters into their own hands.Trystan Andrews, Arran Paterson and Callum Hastings recently launched a clothing business for outdoor wear.Describing bothybothy, the group said: ldquoWe always view bothy trips as a method of escape and re-setting our minds.ldquoWe were thankful for this discovery and thought it would be cruel not to share our passion for this magnicent aspect of le.ldquoOur comfortable clothes will remind you that there is always an option to escape the pressure of the modern world.ldquoThe name bothybothy was chosen as it is how we live our le. Simply waiting for the opportunity for another bothy trip.Currently, the company sells three T-shirt designs and one jumper design, with the potential for a wider range in the future.Bothybothy came to le after Callum combined his savings with those of Trystan and Arran, both . Callum recently turned .When this newspaper asked the group to identy the best thing about running their own business, they replied that they work how and when they choose.ldquoWe donrsquot need to report to anyone above us because we are all equals in this venture and make every decision as a group.They added: ldquoOur advice is to spend time researching all aspects thoroughly before ing straight in.Another fashion-minded Borderer is Ellen McFadzen, a -year-old from Selkirk.She had tohome from France when COVID- put a stop to her travel plans in March.However, she has used her spare time to pursue her love of fashion ndash and she now owns her own business.LoveNelle offers a made-to-measure range as well as bespoke garments. Ellen makes her own patterns, orders the fabrics, and markets the products.ldquoIrsquom quite a hands-on person who wants to do everything myself, said Ellen. ldquoBut my advice to young entrepreneurs is: lsquoDonrsquot be afraid to ask for helprsquo.ldquoI went into this not knowing how I could turn what I loved doing into a business, but here I am.Ellen was taught to sew by her granny and her hobby progressed during lockdown as she documented her style online for her friends and family.They encouraged her to pursue her sewing dream and turn her needle skills into a business.Ellen said: ldquoI love clothes that are more flamboyant than those you would traditionally find in stores.ldquoI want to break through fast fashion and throw-away culture by helping people embrace their quirks and not strive to follow each trend.ldquoI also want to make clothes that fit people without the stress of meeting standard shop sizes.

title: expanding-shielding-scheme-not-actively-considered---jenrick

title: nasa-astronauts-edging-closer-first-splashdown-return-45-years
story: Two Nasa astronauts are on the last leg of their journey home as they prepare to make the first splashdownto Earth in  years.Robert Behnken and Douglas Hurley left the International Space Station after two months on the orbiting laboratory.The pair are expected to land in the ocean off the coast of Florida at around .pm UK time on Sunday.Mr Behnken and Mr Hurley made history on May  when they became the first people to launch into low-Earth orbit on a commercial spacecraft, built by SpaceX.Their mission, named Demo-, also marked the first time Nasa had launched astronauts from US soil in nine years.SpaceXrsquos astronaut carrier, the Crew Dragon, is expected to land in the water off Pensacola, western Florida.The US space agency said this location is far away from Hurricane Isaias, which is expected to hit the eastern part of the state.The last time astronauts made an ocean landing was on July  during an Apollo mission.vw,vw,px, px"Since then, they have always landed on terra firma, using Nasarsquos Space Shuttle or the Russian space agencyrsquos Soyuz capsules.If all goes to plan, the splashdown will usher in a new era for Nasa, which will have at least one commercial spacecraft ready to launch astronauts into space from US soil.The splashdown is the final step in the mission designed to test SpaceXrsquos human spaceflight system ndash including launch, docking, splashdown and recovery operations.In a post-launch conference back in May, Elon Musk ndash the founder of SpaceX ndash said he was not keen to ldquodeclare victory yet, emphasising that the ldquo can be more dangerous than the ascent.Mr Musk said at the time: ldquoWe need to bring them home safely and make sure that we are doing everything we can to minimise that risk of re-entry.Crew Dragonrsquos flight back to Earth with @AstroBehnkenand @Astro_Dougremains on track targeting splashdown off the coast of Pensacola, Florida in the Gulf of Mexico at : p.m. EDT today https:t.co bJFjLCzWdKmdash SpaceXAugust , The Crew Dragon performed manoeuvres to lower the capsulersquos orbit and get it closer to the splashdown zone.The spacecraft is expected to perform another manoeuvre, known as de-orbit burn, which will place it on a trajectory for splashdown, travelling at about ,mph.On entering the Earthrsquos atmosphere, the Crew Dragon will face temperatures of around ,C as it deploys parachutes to slow its speed to around mph.At the point of splashdown, the capsule will be descending at around mph.The re-entry will create a communications blackout, caused by an envelope of hot air surrounding the capsule, which is expected to last about six minutes.GO Navigator makes its way to the primary splashdown zone off the coast of Pensacola, Florida for @AstroBehnkenand @Astro_Dougs . #zwj####Listen in to learn how the recovery vessel will hoist @SpaceX#CrewDragonEndeavour with our astronauts inside # pic CFiVVAzCrmdash Johnson Space CenterAugust , A SpaceX recovery ship called Go Navigator ndash made up of spacecraft engineers, recovery experts and medical professionals ndash will be waiting to pull the capsule aboard and help the astronauts get out as they begin readjusting to gravity.The re-entry will mark the end of SpaceXrsquos human spaceflight demonstration mission.The aerospace companyrsquos first operational flight is expected to take place in September, where a second Crew Dragon spacecraft will carry four astronauts to the space station.The capsule that carried Mr Hurley and Mr Behnken into space will be refurbished and launched on SpaceXrsquos second operational crewed mission, Crew , due to take place early next year.Another aerospace company, Boeing, is also developing spacecraft to ferry astronauts to the space station, as title: east-lothians-football-teams-back-september
story: The countyrsquos six senior football teams have been left on the sidelines since March, when the coronavirus pandemic brought the season to a premature close.Now, early discussions have identied a possible start for the new campaign.The Lowland East South West Pyramid group ndash representing teams from the Scottish Lowland Football League, the East of Scotland Football League, the South of Scotland Football League and the West of Scotland Football League ndash held its first Zoom call earlier this month.Clubs are hoping to restart training in the coming weeks, with a view to playing again at the end of September or beginning of October.Managers from East Lothianrsquos teams cautiously welcomed the announcement and hoped it was the start of light at the end of the tunnel.Geoff Jones, manager of Dunbar United, said: ldquoI think, to be honest, it is an enormous boost.ldquoNot just from a football perspective but just a mental health perspective as well ndash for a lot of people to get back to doing some level of group interaction.ldquoWe have pushed ndash as have a lot of clubs ndash inidual training programmes through virtual apps, like Strava, but some people are highly motivated and others find it dficult outwith a group environment.Meanwhile, Johnny Harvey was looking forward to starting his first full season in charge of Tranent Juniors, having been appointed in February.The Foresters Park side will be looking to build on a promising campaign, which saw them sitting fourth in the East of Scotland Football League Premier Division when the season was stopped.Harvey said: ldquoTo get some kind of normality back in everybodyrsquos lives would be a huge boost.ldquoSupporters, players, myself ndash everybody is exactly the same and is excited to get back on the field as soon as possible.Kevin McDonald, manager at Musselburgh Athletic, was frustrated to see football halted in the spring with his side on an impressive run of form, including securing a place in this seasonrsquos Scottish Cup after a - thumping of Mid Annandale in the South and East Shield.Now, he is hoping to see that continue when the upcoming campaign gets under way.He said: ldquoI have been pestering the secretary at Musselburgh to find outhe has any information.ldquoWe are all desperate to get back ndash myself and the players are the same.ldquoWe will be looking at a seven-month break by the time we restart games.ldquoThe sooner we are allowed to get back training and playing friendlies the better.ldquoI think we will need more friendlies with not playing for so long as well.Joe Hamill, player-manager at Haddington Athletic, said everyone at the club was keen to see the season get back under way.He stressed that training could look slightly dferent than it did previously, with stringent cleaning measures being put in place to prevent the spread of the coronavirus.He said: ldquoItrsquos a wee bit of light at the end of the tunnel for us. Irsquove been getting messages from the players asking lsquowhen are we starting back rsquoldquoIrsquom in the same boat and just want to get on with it.

title: special-tv-appearance-family-tiktok-marathon
story: Eight-year-old Mary Kidd, mum Karen, dad Gordon and older sister Abbie, , appeared on Martin and Romanrsquos Sunday Best on Sunday, July , the pairrsquos chat show style programme.They appeared on the show, presented by father-and-son duo Martin and Roman Kemp, thanks to Maryrsquos six-hour TikTok dance marathon, which she completed on VE Day in aid of the Walk With Scott Foundation.Karen, a board member at the foundation, said: ldquoI got a message on Facebook from a producer at Cactus TV [an independent TV production company which owns runs the show], they were looking for inspirational families for the show.ldquoI was a wee bit unsure at first but the girl we spoke to was nice.ldquoThey saw Maryrsquos story online, I think it was the Courier online, and askedthey could give us a phone call.ldquoSo we had a couple of phone calls with them and they found out what happened and about the charity etc, like a pre-interview.ldquoRoman is also a big TikTok fan so he was really interested.The show was filmed on June  and took about one hour and  minutes in total to record. It was broadcast on STV ITV at .am last Sunday morning, July .As well as chats with actor and Spandau Ballet member Martin Kemp and his radio DJ and Irsquom a Celebrity... Get Me Out Of Here! star son Roman, the family played some games and spoke to the showrsquos three guests Laura Whitmore, Beverly Knight and Jessie Ware.Karen said: ldquoWe just had normal chats with them, they made us feel very, very welcome. The whole experience was really good. They had some great chats with Mary.ldquoMartin and Roman were so nice and made us feel very at ease.ldquoI was more of a Duran Duran fan but I didnrsquot tell him that!ldquoItrsquos nice that they are recognising kids that have done something that wee bit dferent.ldquoIt was also nice to see what it takes to film a TV show and how it is all done ndash Roman fluffed his lines a couple of times. It was an honour and a privilege to have had the opportunity from ITV.Ahead of watching the show, Karen admitted she was nervous.However, afterwards she described it as ldquoone of the most surreal experiences and said she was really pleased with how the show turned out.She said that both Mary and Abbie also loved filming the show.She added a thanks to Mary for doing her TikTok challenge, which raised more than pound, for the Walk With Scott Foundation.

title: great-grandmother-celebrates-95th-birthday-95-plus-cards
story: Betty Sneddonwas delighted when relatives paid her a visit on Sunday to wish her many happy s and enjoy a socially distanced party in the garden of her town centre home.She did not want any gts but her family thought it would be a great ideashe received  cards ndash reflecting her age ndash from well-wishers.The number of cards sent has now surpassed the target as relatives and friends, some from abroad, inundated her with birthday messages, much to her surprise and amazement.During the Covid- lockdown, Mrs Sneddon enjoyed spending time in her beloved garden. She was also grateful to a friend who left cakes for her and gave her a wave.Her daughter Mary Blair kept her in touch with family via FaceTime but she was delighted to catch up with them in person on her birthday amid the easing of restrictions.The last surviving member of a family of nine ndash five brothers and four sisters ndash Mrs Sneddon was born in Musselburghrsquos Newbigging, where she first attended school.She was a pupil at Burgh Primary School and went on to secondary school at Fisherrow. She also lived for a time in Kilwinning.On leaving school, she was employed as a housemaid at Inveresk for a short time and also worked at Bruntonrsquos Wire Mill, Musselburgh. She also enjoyed working at LrsquoAperit, a restaurant in Edinburgh.She met her future husband Jimmy Sneddon when he was staying in lodgings in Musselburgh while working as a steel erector at Portobello Power Station. The couple were married at Inveresk Manse and set up home on Moir Avenue.Mrs Sneddon was a soprano and soloist in the famous Musselburgh Fishwives Choir.They sang all over the country and once went to sing for soldiers in recovery after the Second World War at Peel Hospital near Peebles. Her older brother Jim was recovering at the hospital from a severe back injury.A mum of three, grandmother of five and great grandmother of three, she has always filled her le with family and friends.Over the years, she enjoyed attending the Womenrsquos Rural Institute and playing Scrabble with Nancy Herkes, her best friend from school, until they were in their late seventies.A fan of detective programmes and brain-teasers, she said her recipe for a long and happy le was ldquocrosswords, Scrabble, gardening and great grandchildren keep you going ndash not forgetting Morse, Poirot and, of course, good genes.

title: bid-drive-thru-coffee-shop-eyesore-service-area
story: The Motor Fuel Group has applied to East Lothian Council for planning permission to build a coffee shop with drive-thru and create additional car parking.There would also be a new dedicated entrance to serve the adjacent Travelodge hotel.More than  jobs would be created as a result of the development.The hotel used to share an entrance with the now vacant Burger King and Little Chef restaurants, which closed several years ago.The site is located close to Old Craighall Roundabout which connects the A Edinburgh City Bypass to the A.North of the site is the B that connects to Monktonhall and then Musselburgh beyond, with the town centre .km from the service area.Tony Thomas, director of East Linton-based APT Planning and Development, said: ldquoThe plan is to demolish part of the original building complex that previously housed Burger King and Little Chef, and create a more dedicated and convenient car park for the Travelodge.ldquoOn the western part of the site we are proposing a drive-thru coffee outlet. Apart from that, the site will be landscaped and upgraded.He said that the current petrol station there, also owned by the Motor Fuel Company, would remain in use.Mr Thomas could not yet say which company would run the drive-thru coffee shop however, an image of the proposed outlet shows a logo for Starbucks.He said it was hoped the work would be completed within a yearplanning consent was granted.A landscape design report, submitted with the planning application, said the ldquoenhanced car park arrangement would provide nine accessible parking bays close to the building entrances and five electric car charging points.It added: ldquoWith the proposed coffee shop there is an opportunity to provide two areas of external seating ndash these have been carefully sited to maximise a south-facing aspect so that visitors can make the most of sunshine.ldquoBoth of these seating areas have plant beds located close by.ldquoThese beds will help to create a sense of enclosure."These plant beds will be planted with a iety of trees, shrubs and hardy perennial plants that will provide seasonal interest.ldquoThe plants will also help to screen any queuing cars into the drive-thru.ldquoTo the front of the retained Travelodge building, we have proposed another plant bed, planted with native trees ndash birch and rowan ndash and robust groundcover.ldquoElsewhere in the new car park, we have looked to punctuate the space with street trees these trees will help to provide vertical structure to the space.ldquoThe proposals look to retain the dense group of semi-mature trees to the west of the site.ldquoTo the north of the site there is a row of sycamore trees that will also be retained.ldquoWith the demolition of the building, there will be a gap in these trees and it is proposed that an additional four sycamore trees are planted to complete the row.ldquoThese trees will work as a buffer between the new car park and the road.ldquoTo make way for the development we are proposing to remove five small trees within the car park that have failed to establish.Other tree planting will take place around the site.Irene Tait, chair of Musselburgh  Inveresk Community Council, welcomed the plan, saying: ldquoIt is an eyesore at the moment and something needed to be done for a while ndash as long as the landscaping fits in with the rest of the area.Ward councillor Stuart Currie, who is not a member of the councilrsquos planning committee, added: ldquoA big part of the site has been lying empty for some time and has become a real eyesore.ldquoThe entire site is already set up as a drive-thru facility alongside the hotel so, as long as itrsquos contained within the current boundary [Irsquom happy to support it].ldquoIt will create jobs and be brought back into full use from a boarded-up building.Kenny MacAskill, East Lothianrsquos MP, said: ldquoThere seems merit in it."Itrsquos a gap site and the facilities would enhance the area.ldquoAs long as it abides by any criteria set by council, the work and project seem welcome.

title: pictures-prestonpans-lockdown-gala-day
story: Like many events in the county, the annual Prestonpans Childrenrsquos Gala was impacted by the ongoing coronavirus pandemic.The galarsquos organising committee had several discussions and, following advice from both East Lothian Council and the Scottish Government, it first postponed and then cancelled the gala day, which had been due to be held on June .However, the committee still wanted to recognise and mark the day.One suggestion was to give all of those in the royal court a goodie bag and rename the event, so instead it held what it called lsquoLockdown Gala Dayrsquo.Graeme Hutchison, gala convenor, told the Courier: ldquoThis was to encourage the kids and remind them that we hadnrsquot forgotten that this should have been their special day.ldquoThis idea kind of grew thanks to our chairperson Vikki Burns suggesting we could have an alternative gala day parade.The parade consisted of the gala committee members decorating their cars with balloons and bows in gala colours.They then travelled around Prestonpans, stopping at the houses of each member of the royal court to deliver them their goodie bag, honking their horns as they passed.Graeme said: ldquoIn the lead-up to gala day there was still a buzz about the town people were still showing their support by putting up their bunting and the parents of the royal court were being made aware we would be visiting. Nobody knew what to expect.ldquoGala day itself was amazing, from the glorious weather to the great response we got from the locals as we travelled around in convoy tooting and waving, visiting many streets of the town which the normal gala parade doesnrsquot visit. The people of Prestonpans certainly came out to show their support and for that we are truly grateful.ldquoWe would like to take this opportunity to thank the future Queen Lily [Bennion] and her royal court, as well as their families for their patience and understanding. Thanks to Connor from Sneddon Media for travelling with us and capturing the fantastic photos, which are on our Facebook page lsquoPrestonpans Gala Dayrsquo.ldquoFinally, thanks to the dedicated committee members who once again gave up their time to make the event possible.ldquoWe hope to be back doing some fundraisers in the not too distant future to help us fund and prepare as we look forward to Gala Day  on Saturday, June .After Lockdown Gala Day, Graeme took to social media to share his thoughts on the event.He said: ldquoPrestonpans, you didnrsquot disappoint us.ldquoThe fantastic efforts made from everyone to put up your bunting and decorate your streets, please repeat this next year. It was great to see so many of you as we travelled around as many streets as we could while visiting the members of the royal court.ldquoTo the royal court children, we didnrsquot want to forget that it would have been your day, we can still have your special day next year.ldquoTo Queen Lily, you were absolutely stunning, even reducing some of the committee to tears your mum and dad will be proud of you, the way you conducted yourself on what should have been your special day. To you, the community of Prestonpans for coming out and showing your appreciation as we passed by quietlyin our cars, doing the alternative gala parade. Hopefully you enjoyed it.He also thanked his fellow gala committee members for giving up their time and ensuring gala day traditions continued.

title: pop-up-cycle-lane-coastal-road
story: While mph speed limits are being introduced in Prestonpans and Cockenzie and Port Seton.As part of the Spaces for People initiative to provide additional space for physical distancing to protect public health, work has started on a temporary cycle route between Prestonpans and Cockenzie and Port Seton which will run parallel to the main B Edinburgh Road.The three-metre wide path will be created by laying hard surfacing down on the grass verge on the north side of the carriageway between the two communities.The path will run alongside the footpath between the boatyard access at Prestonpans to just past the old power station with a white line separating the cyclepath and walkway.This is the councilrsquos latest project to improvesocial distancing in the wake of the Covid- crisis.The local authority received pound.million from the Scottish Governmentrsquos Spaces for People fund to introduce ious countywide measures to make it easier to social distance in town centres and improve cycle and pedestrian paths.As well as the roadside cycle route, the speed limit on Edinburgh Road, which is normally mph, will be reduced to mph and speed limits in the twocommunities reduced to just mph.The plan for the cycle path has seen dozens of painted stones created by local schoolchildren, which line the footpath, move across to the other side of the road.The stones are a symbol of hope and unity during the Covid- crisis, and many similar displays have been created throughout East Lothian and the whole country.Councillor Norman Hampshire, environment spokesperson at East Lothian Council, said: ldquoWe received many comments in the public consultation around Spaces for People on the need to provide suitable space for people cycling.ldquoMany people are currently cycling this route and we need to cater for the current increase in cyclists during the pandemic period.ldquoIn common with other Spaces for People measures, this route is for temporary use as we gradually move out of restrictions and will also provide a viable alternative to the use of the private car and or public transport for shorter-distanced essential or leisure trips in the area.The works also include the introduction of temporary crossings of Edinburgh Road at either end of the route through the use of lsquobuildoutsrsquo and bolt-down bollards.In addition, the proposals also include traffic calming measures on Edinburgh Road to slow down traffic with a temporary reduction in the speed limit to mph between the two communities, in tandem with the introduction of mph limits within the communities themselves.MrHampshire added: ldquoWe were aware of a collection of painted stones that have been carefully laid by local schoolchildren alongside the existing footway along Edinburgh Road and recognise that these are important to the local community.ldquoThe community council arranged for these to be carefully collected prior to the start of the works and they have been relocated on the other side of the road.

title: hot-tub-suites-looking-sea-among-new-plans-hotel
story: The ambitious proposals would see a three-storey building built between the Bayswell Park Hotel and the clfs to the north.Nine new suites could be created as part of the plans, which would also see a new restaurant built.According to a supporting statement included within the planning application: ldquoThe existing business model is barely sustainable, and the overarching objective of the development is to invest c.pound, in infrastructure improvements to secure the future of the hotel.ldquoThe development proposals will address weaknesses, strengthen the enterprise, promote higher occupancy levels, deliver a much-improved standard of service that will attract customers and, most importantly, facilitate the delivery of a top-quality hotel.The proposals would see changes made to the existing hotel building, as well as the construction of a new annexe.Inside the hotel, which dates back more than  years, four single rooms would be altered to create two double twin rooms.On the western side of the hotel, which is on the townrsquos Bayswell Park, a new dining area would be created.The new -cover restaurant and improved lounge bar would see the removal of the conservatory and the construction of ldquogreatly improved facilities.According to the supporting statement: ldquoThe present areas are too small, and the new restaurant and lounge bar will provide a spacious attractive welcoming ambiance. The comfortable, high-quality dining and relaxation space will be available for both resident guests and for non-resident clients.The new annexe would offer visitors impressive views over the clfs and out to the North Sea.Drawings show the three-storey building ndash with three suites on each floor ndash built into the sloping land, with outdoor hot tubs.The statement reads: ldquoThe existing hot tub suites are spectacularly unique incredibly popular and are delivering high premium occupancy rates and attracting guests to Dunbar from all over Scotland and from the north of England.ldquoThe present number and type of letting rooms is not sufficient to sustain a business model which includes a very high level of service provision ndash particularly when some potential revenue income sources are not deliverableor have greatly declinedndash over recent years.ldquoConsolidation of four single rooms into two double twin rooms will result in the number of bedrooms within the hotel being reduced by two, with the combined proposals showing a net increase of seven rooms.Other works proposed for the hotel include the installation of a lt and ambulant toilet facilities, as well as improving the parking outside the hotel.The proposed developments, which are being weighed up by East Lothian Councilrsquos planning department, are the latest changes at the hotel, which currently has  bedrooms and five suites.In , a dining room and conservatory extension was built, and in  a decked area and four private hot tubs were added.Community councillors in the town had mixed views on the proposals, which were discussed on Monday evening.Jacquie Bell, secretary of the group, said there were neighbours who were ldquoreally, really concerned about the proposals.She noted that social media had also given a mixed picture, with some questioning the design of the annexe building and the safety of building on that area of land.However, community councillor Craig Rapson said: ldquoThere is a need for hotel accommodation in Dunbar.ldquoComments about safety issues ndash they are not going to build somethingit is not safe.George Robertson, also a community councillor, agreed that there was a need for improved accommodation in the town and felt the scheme could not be ldquocondemned out right.Ahead of the meeting, Pippa Swan, chairwoman of the group, said that there were mixed views within the community council.She said: ldquoI think we as a community council are going to be guided somewhat by the response of the neighbours.ldquoThe feedback from the community council has been mixed.ldquoThere is a genuine support for anything that would bring a high-quality addition to the accommodation offered in Dunbar.

title: column-frustrated-tories-power-grab
story: The Tory Government is trying to put in place a UK internal market following Brexit, where the devolved UK nations would have to adhere to Westminsterrsquos standards in future trade deals.The proposal would mean that Scotland would lose out on the power to agree to rules which would affect us, and decisions made in Westminster would be imposed on Scotland and the other devolved nations.Given Boris Johnsonrsquos track record, we know what this means for the UK and we should expect ridiculous trade deals with Trump which donrsquot meet basic standards.Though it seems currently that this is simply a constitutional argument, it is important that we realise the threat that this presents to our trade going forward.We do not want to see lowered food standards, or diminished safety standards on our goods.Clearly, Westminster are trying to push through a policy that means the Scottish, Welsh and Northern Irish Parliaments do not get a say in these matters, and it is important that we make sure this doesnrsquot happen.The Prime Minister seems to be in a panic over polls which show a majority for independence and is visiting Scotland to repair broken relationships as a result, but the Scottish people have had their eyes opened and seen the dangers of trusting a Tory Government.The coronavirus pandemic has proven their values, and we deserve a government that prioritises its people and their safety.I welcome the reopening of beauty salons and hairdressers and I know that this will be a relief for the many business owners who are seeking to reopen their salons, as well as to those who make use of their services.Beauty salons and hairdressers make a valuable contribution to our economy and I am glad that they will once again resume their business.

title: pans-snake-slithers-across-road-new-home
story: The Pans Snake has stretched from the eastern edge of Prestonpans towards neighbouring Cockenzie and Port Seton since it was born at the beginning of April.However, with plans for a temporary cycle path to be created beside busy Edinburgh Road, the snake had to find a new home... on the other side of the road.Emma Orphant was among those spending  minutes on Sunday evening moving the snake from the north side of the road.She said: ldquoWe lost count of the number of stones at ,!ldquoWe moved them across the road because the council are putting in a temporary cycle path.ldquoOn Sunday, volunteers and children moved them across the road.ldquoIt has just been a nice thing for people when they are out for a walk to look for.ldquoIt is for the kids.Youngsters and adults started working on the Pans Snake at the beginning of April, with lockdown restrictions in effect.Similar schemes have taken place where across the country, including the Windygoul Worm in Tranent.The snake started at the bus stop beside the Greenhills at Prestonpans, with Emma, who is depute manager at Seahorse Nursery in Cockenzie, keen to see it stretch the near half-mile to the neighbouring village.Emma, who lives in Prestonpans, was pleased to say that the snake had been a success and admitted she had a few favourite stones.She picked out those from youngsters saying they were missing school or with messages including their name and teacherrsquos name from school as her favourites.Beyond the coronavirus, Emma ndash and a number of people on social media ndash was keen to see the snake find a permanent home, with the possibility of the stones being cemented into the wall beside the footpath.

title: beach-boardwalk-look-blooming-great-thanks-volunteers
story: The team has been working hard over the last fortnight to create plant beds along one side of the walkway as it carries out landscaping work on the site.The boardwalk was created two years ago across the road from the holiday village to provide easy access to the beach for wheelchair users and, thanks to grants from the Walk With Scott Foundation and Beach Wheelchairs charity, two beach wheelchairs are available to borrow from Seton Sands.Cockenzie and Port Seton In Bloom said that the boardwalk, which also has three picnic tables and seats, had become a popular place for locals and holidaymakers all year round and members were delighted to be able to start work on its surroundings.A spokesperson said: ldquoIt was always our intention to landscape the area around the boardwalk and we are delighted that this work has finally got under way.ldquoOver the last two weeks, members of Cockenzie and Port Seton In Bloom, assisted by several enthusiastic and hard-working volunteers, have transformed one side of the boardwalk.ldquoA long raised bed has been sited alongside the pavement.ldquoA rockery has been created at the beginning of the boardwalk.ldquoSoil was provided by East Lothian Council and the areas planted up with plants suitable for the exposed situation near the sea, which will, in time, provide colour and interest for most of the summer.ldquoIn due course, we hope to make similar improvements to the other side of the boardwalk.

title: longniddry-gala-strikes-virtual-gold-50th-anniversary
story: The gala committee held a childrenrsquos disco in February but the committee still wanted to do something to remember the occasion so that it did not pass without a mention.Instead of its traditional celebrations, a competition was held which encouraged village residents to decorate their window, or more, with anything golden. A number of entries were submitted from people all over the village.First place went to Meg Anderson of Douglas Road second to Elizabeth Anderson-Whymark of Dean Road and third to Joanne Breckenridge of John Knox Road.To support local businesses, all of the winners were given East Lothian gt cards.Suzanne Low, Longniddry Gala committee member, said: ldquoWe would like to thank everyone who took part with golden decor ndash very good effort, I think yoursquoll agree.The committee hopes to celebrate the anniversary when possible.

title: luxury-hampers-given-students-covid-19-efforts
story: A total of pound, has been allocated by Santander Universities to provide gts to , students at QMU and Edinburgh Napier University who supported the NHS in the fight against the virus.QMU has offered its nursing and allied health professionsrsquo students on the frontline a choice of one of two luxury food hampers ndash a lsquopamper hamperrsquo or breakfast hamper.The gts have been provided by Artisan Larder Scotland, founded by QMU graduate David McVey.Edinburgh Napier University has linked up with East Lothian-based sushi company Minato Sushi to offer its own eligible School of Health and Social Care students a pound voucher for the business as a thank you for their efforts as part of the countryrsquos Covid- response.Sir Paul Grice, principal and vice-chancellor of Queen Margaret University, said: ldquoWe are incredibly proud of all of our students from the School of Health Sciences, especially those who are playing their part in the NHSrsquos fight against Covid-.ldquoThanks to the continuing generosity and support of Santander Universities, we have been able to not only provide this thank you gt for hundreds of our hard-working health students but also support one of our graduate businesses in the process."I hope the students enjoy the gt ndash they are doing fantastic work.

title: 50-000-secures-future-youth-organisation-recharge
story: Recharge, which works with young people aged from  to  in the Farsquoside area, was given the five-figure sum by The Robertson Trust.The pound, goes towards the managerrsquos position, starting next January.Alan Bell, manager at Recharge, was delighted with the funding announcement.He said: ldquoIt is massive, especially this year. This was the last year of our current funding and we did not have any beyond that.ldquoTo receive three years of funding has confirmed the future of the organisation.Mr Bell, who has been involved with the group for more than a decade, said the organisation provided support for young people.The coronavirus pandemic had changed how the organisation worked, with services instead moving online.However, as restrictions ease, Mr Bell was confident those services would start to go back to the way they were.It is also hoped they could be back in their Tranent base this autumn.Councillor Colin McGinn, who represents the Tranent, Wallyford and Macmerry ward, is a trustee of Recharge.He too was delighted with the funding announcement and highlighted the importance of Mr Bell.He said: ldquoIrsquom absolutely delighted because it is a crucial bit of funding for us.ldquoAlan Bell is so key to that and Recharge running well. His influence is fantastic and it really, really helps us planning for the next year.Recharge works with young people to help increase their confidence, esteem and skills.Support is also given to young people and families with issues that are affecting them.Instead of face-to-face meetings, Recharge has been mainly working remotely and supporting young people through video links and phone calls, as well as pulling together a webpage of resources that can be accessed at home.The Robertson Trustrsquos mission is to improve the quality of le and realise the potential of Scotlandrsquos people and communities, with a particular focus on health, social and educational inequalities across Scotland.

title: tesco-seeks-drop-cash-obligation
story: The company says it no longer owns land ndash the site of its former store at Mall Avenue ndash which is to be turned into  flats by a developer.Tesco has applied to East Lothian Council to mody a contract which was part of an earlier planning consent for residential development at the town centre site, dating back to .The sum of pound, had to be given for extra accommodation at Musselburgh Burgh Primary School and Musselburgh Grammar School.Pritchett Planning Consultancy, on behalf of Tesco Stores Limited, said Tesco now owned and operated the supermarket and petrol filling station at Olivebank Road.It stated: ldquoTesco was previously involved in a land transaction which enabled residential development to be constructed on the site of the former Tesco store site. This transaction took place over a decade ago and the land of the residential development site is not owned by Tesco.ldquoThe section  agreement states that Tesco Stores Limited shall pay an education contribution relating to a residential development on land identied as the third subjects.ldquoTesco has no ownership of the subject site and is not involved in any way in developing the land for residential purposes.The document added: ldquoThis proposed modication to the section  agreement by Tesco seeks to remove Tescorsquos name from the agreement and to replace this with the lsquothird proprietorsrsquo as owners of the residential land on the third subject site.ldquoIn making this change, the agreement would be more aligned with government policy on legal obligations as the agreement would bind the landowner to which the agreement relates rather than a third party which has no involvement in the land or its development.

title: new-art-exhibition-highlights-beauty-dunbar
story: Edinburgh-based Ann Cowan spent time in the town throughout  and earlier this year.Her work ndash Dunbar Sketchbooks ndash will feature in Gullanersquos Fidra Fine Art, alongside Dominique Cameronrsquos Moor, which focuses on Rannoch Moor, west of Pitlochry.Although not the intention of either artist, both bodies of work are devoid of human figures.Ann, the daughter of an architect and an artist, found that her eye was naturally drawn to the architecture and streets in and around Dunbar.She said: ldquoThe town has a wealth of beautul old red sandstone buildings with interesting architectural details.ldquoOrange pan tiles form wonderful roofscapes.ldquoThe industrial outskirts are grittier, but just as interesting in terms of composition.ldquoThe harbour is a constant source of inspiration with its fishing boats and lobster creels.ldquoFollow the clfs of deep burnt sienna along the coast, past Winterfield to Belhaven and you discover miles of sandy beach with tall ochre grasses set against colourful beach chalets.Ann gave up a career in law to become a full-time artist.She grew up in the Borders, with Dunbar a town she has known for many years.Alan Rae, who owns the gallery, was a fan of both artists and was looking forward to the exhibition, which gets under way on August .He said: ldquoAnnrsquos loose and expressive drawing, sometimes supported by textural patches of collage, combines with an organic palette enlivened with flashes blue, yellow and the rich red of the local East Lothian sandstone.ldquoPainted in a spontaneous sketchbook style, the result is a broad and tender portrait of a much-loved town.The gallery owner said that the coronavirus lockdown had proven dficult for the arts sector.Fidra Fine Arts reopened its doors at the end of last month with the Mixed Summer Exhibition.Mr Rae added: ldquoWhen the lockdown began, it was a really anxious time.ldquoGallery owners always want to do the best for their artists and I wasnrsquot sure how it would play out with this exhibition.ldquoHappily, we will be welcoming visitors to view this wonderful work in August.

title: teenager-interviews-legends-scottish-football
story: Angus Blacklock has spent lockdown tracking down some of Scottish footballrsquos best-known faces and speaking to them for his new YouTube channel.The youngster is keen to get into sports journalism when he leaves North Berwick High School and has made a start by interviewing famous names.He said: ldquoFrom an early age, I knew I was never going to be a footballer.ldquoI always wanted to have a career in sport and football really.ldquoI like listening to podcasts and wanted to get into the media. Hopefully, this puts me in good stead and is a good thing to have on your CV.The -year-old had been thinking about launching the online channel but found himself without the time to do it due to schoolwork.It was during an online course with Youth Football Scotlandthat the idea started to take shape.He said: ldquoMy first interview was with John Collins, who lives nearby.ldquoI was nervous and did already know him and had spoken to him but not in depth about his career.ldquoIt was good to speak to him about that.Since speaking to the former Hibs, Celtic and Monaco midfielder, who famously scored for Scotland against Brazil in the World Cup in , Angus has continued to interview big names.Often a chat with one former player led to a chat with another ndash assuming they were happy to pass on contact details for the next interviewee!Angus said: ldquoProbably the most high profile would be John Hartson [former Arsenal, Celtic and Wales striker]. Irsquove spoken to Ryan McGowan [who scored for Hearts against Hibs in the  Scottish Cup], former Courier reporter Joel Sked, Kevin Murphy [manager of Hearts Women] and Gary Locke [Scottish Cup winner with Hearts].Angus also interviewed John Hughes, who led Inverness Caledonian Thistle to the Scottish Cup in .Now, the teenage season ticket holder at Tynecastle has targeted securing an interview with Heartsrsquo new first-team head coach Robbie Neilson and ing number one Craig Gordon.The Aberlady resident told the Courier he had loved football since he was five years old.His dad, Robin, is no stranger to the beautul game either.In , Robin took on the EuroChampsChallenge, where he set off on a ,-mile car trek that took him to the home stadium of every football team to have ever won the European Cup Champions League.At that time,  clubs in  cities across  countries had lted the top prize in European football, with Angus visiting Celtic Park, Anfield and Old Trafford before his dad travelled overseas.The memorable trip saw Robin and friends raise pound, for charities Changing Faces and the Sick Kids Friendsrsquo Foundation, now the Edinburgh Childrenrsquos Hospital Charity.To view Angusrsquo videos, go to YouTube and search for Angus Blacklock.

title: covid-19-testing-centre-returns-former-power-station-site
