title: business owners say social distancing measures wrecking penarth
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityOn Tuesday ldquoscrew in bollards replaced temporary cones and steel barriers along Glebe Street, Windsor Road and where in the town to stop cars from parking in bays, allowing for pedestrians to socially distance.A petition which was started on Thursday calling on the Vale council to reconsider the parking measures has attracted more than  signatures online.Butcher Marcus Lush of David Lush Butchers on Glebe Street, explained his frustration when he said a representative of Vale council arrived on Wednesday morning to ldquoglue down the bollards.Marcus Lush said Glebe Street on Saturday was very quiet. He says he would usually have queues around the corner.ldquoThey put bollards in my loading bay on Tuesday morning, he said, ldquoI was annoyed but I was informed they could be removed, as they were screwed in.ldquoKnowing this, I did screw them out to allow for my morning deliveries, of which I have many and the drivers need to park close to the shop to carry the produce on their shoulders.ldquoI was shocked on Wednesday morning when someone from the council turned up to stick the bollards to the floor so I could no longer remove them.ldquoIt means my delivery drivers are having to carry huge amounts of produce on their back for well over an hour, when it would usually take about  minutes.ldquoItrsquos unsustainable and inhumane. It also means our business isnrsquot efficient.The Vale council says the measures were implemented based on government guidance and discussion with representatives of tradersrsquo groups in Penarth, as well as the town council.Shoppers have said they have been going where due to the restrictions, and it is deterring them for shopping locally, while others have said it could be a good thing for the town.Cllr Lis Burnett, Vale of Glamorgan Council Cabinet Member for Education and Regeneration, said: ldquoThe safety of shoppers visiting town centres in the Vale is our number one priority and so measures designed to promote social distancing and protect people have been introduced in these locations.ldquoThis has involved removing some parking bays in order to create more safe space for pedestrians at pinch points in the towns.ldquoThe new more stream-lined fixed bollards are less overpowering in the street scene and after the most recent review the number of parking bays affected has been reduced to specic pinch-points.ldquoWe continue to meet with town councils and business representatives and will regularly review the measures to ensure they reflect the changing situation in our shopping centres. In this way we hope to support local businesses while encouraging shoppers towith confidence to town centres.Mr Lush says to add salt to the wound, since parking restrictions have been put in place, he has seen a noticeable decrease in sales, and this Saturday was one of the quietest he has seen.       ,params: .pushldquoWersquove tried our best through lockdown to remain open and serve the town as well as we can, and I find it very sad that this is how wersquove been repaid by the council, he added., compared to now" alt"Penarth Times: Glebe Street two weeks ago , compared to now" class"editor-image"Glebe Street two weeks ago , compared to nowEmily Hillier, a resident who regularly drives into the town centre to shop, said she was ldquostunned by the bollards when she arrived to do some shopping on Wednesday.ldquoI wasnrsquot the only one either, she said. ldquoSo many people were saying the same thing ndash stood around just bemused by these plans.ldquoI try to use local shops as much as I can, but Irsquove never felt so discouraged to support local shops as a consumer.ldquoItrsquos so sad that we are being discouraged at a time when these local shops need all the help they can get.Ms Hillier said she believes the council should be using the money to fund parking in the town instead, and should allow Penarthrsquos residents to ldquouse their common sense to socially distance.She added that her friends have driven to the town centre this week, and have gone to the supermarket instead because they couldnrsquot find a parking space.The restrictions have garnered some support in the town too, however, and earlier this week members of Penarth Civic Society and Gwyrddio Penarth Greeningsaid they backed a partial pedestrianisation of some of the major pinch points in the town, to allow eateries to operate outdoors.The topic was on the agenda at a town council meeting two weeks ago, and a survey has been rolled out on the council website asking for residentsrsquo views.Gideon Calder of GPG said: ldquoOur town centre needs our support, and whats vital is that people feel safe to visit, spend more time in our town centre, and make the most of our local shops and cafeacutes.Anne Evans of Penarth Civic Society added: ldquoThese proposals would provide safe pedestrian zones to help increase footfall in the town centre, ensure that there is vital outdoor space for cafeacutes and restaurants, and increase the amount of town centre parking. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey title: doubts raised fresh promises act bridge abandoned three years
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityCross Common bridge in Dinas Powys was closed off to drivers in February , after a new access road was built and the safety of the old bridge was questioned.The council abandoned the bridge and put up red and white plastic barriers to stop traffic driving over it.In August last year, the council promised to begin the work to remove the bridge that October mdash after delays in finding a specialist contractor.Now, with the bridge still there a year later, Plaid Cymru community councillors are demanding the council act, and either remove the bridge or turn it into a footpath and clear the debris and plastic barriers.Cllr Chris Franks said: ldquoFor three years, the Vale has said this bridge has got to go. If theyrsquore going to do it, theyrsquove got to get on with it. These ugly barriers are so frustrating, and thousands of people see it.ldquoThey did some excavations and just left the spoil heap. Itrsquos a vast improvement now, but even cleaned up itrsquos still a mess.Jean Webber, who lives nearby on Llwyn Derwen, said she has witnessed a lot of fly-tippers dumping rubbish at the bridge, like fridges, freezers and buildersrsquo rubbish. She said: ldquoI think this end of Dinas has been forgotten. [The council] seems to concentrate on the other end.ldquoI walk past here every day. It wouldnrsquot be so badthey just walled it off. I never complain, but this is just appalling.The council has now promised work will begin to remove the bridge next month, and blamed coronavirus for the most recent delay. The new timetable is to finish the job by this October.A Vale of Glamorgan council spokesperson said: ldquoUnfortunately, the contractor originally appointed to remove the bridge withdrew from the project after agreement couldnrsquot be reached on a claim for additional costs due to the coronavirus pandemic.ldquoThat meant a new contractor had to be found, a process that added to the delay caused by the pandemic itself, which for a period prevented work of this type being carried out.ldquoThe council has now successfully appointed a new contractor and received an indication that work is expected to start in mid-August. It is anticipated the work will be completed by the end of October.But both Cllr Franks and Ms Webber raised doubts about the new timetable. They threaten to damage the reputation of the Penarth Esplanade area and make it less appealing to visitors. With that in mind, it is in everyonersquos interests that the Esplanade remains a safe, family friendly place for everyone to enjoy.ldquoI will soon discuss with my Cabinet colleagues the possibility of introducing a Public Space Protection Order at the Esplanade making it illegal to consume alcohol in public areas.ldquoIn the meantime, Council officers will be carrying out regular checks around this location to make sure alcohol sales comply with the terms of inidual licences and are not contributing to poor behaviour. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log -- s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentSorry, an error occurred.Sign in or register leave a comment or rate a commentOrder byOldest firstNewest firstHighest scoredLowest scoredLoading comments... story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. They also said a trial period will not take place in August and September.Ideas, revealed by the town council in an online questionnaire on Friday, includes a pedestrianised ldquosafe space on Windsor Road from Arcot Street to the roundabout, including the bottom of Lower Glebe Street.Other plans for Windsor Road could include ldquoshared spaces between pedestrians and traffic during set times, while another included only allowing service traffic ndash such as delivery vehicles ndash to access Windsor Road and Lower Glebe Street.One of the major points for discussion is around proposals for a one-way traffic system incorporating Albert Road, Stanwell Road, Hickman Road, Arcot Street,Glebe Street and Ludlow Lane.The grey area marks the safe space pedestrianised proposal.The town council say the one-way system would enable more chevron parking on Plassey Street, Albert Road and Stanwell Road.Ceri McCann, Rachel Came and Karen Hatton at Andrearsquos Flower Boutique on Glebe Street, think the town will sufferpedestrianisation plans go ahead.: Karen Hatton, Ceri McCann and Rachel Came at Andreas Flower Boutique, Glebe Street" alt"Penarth Times: : Karen Hatton, Ceri McCann and Rachel Came at Andreas Flower Boutique, Glebe Street" class"editor-image": Karen Hatton, Ceri McCann and Rachel Came at Andreas Flower Boutique, Glebe StreetldquoPenarth isnrsquot the type of place you come to and spend a day, itrsquos a place people come and park up and quickly do some shopping, they said. ldquoBusinesses are already feeling the impact of lower footfall due to the social distancing parking trials, and to add this to the mix is poor timing.The plans also include additional bus stops, including one right outside Joan Painesrsquo funeral directors.The new ideas are designed to bring an additional  spaces to the town centre, but this is likely to affect residentsShe says buses stopping outside her shop every half an hour - combined with the one-way system - would be likely to cause too much congestion.ldquoMy main concern is the congestion and the impact that will have on my customers, she said. ldquoIt is not nice to have so much noise, fumes, and congestion outside when yoursquore trying to sort out a funeral.Joan and Tony Paines have made a blown up version of the main town area, so people can better understand the ideas.Ms Paines suggested a bus terminal at Station Approach, and said she thinks a one-way system around the town will also cause heavy traffic on smaller roads such as Railway Terrace, Grove Terrace and Woodland Place.Resident and member of Friendsof the Earth Barry andVale Max Wallis said he is in support of partial pedestrianisation, but questioned the one-way system idea.Mr Wallis said that a one-way system would ldquoworsen traffic and add to town centre pollution, adding: ldquoCovid- will force new thinking. People see the benefits of more walking and cycling. Some shops and businesses will close, with more online shopping. The town centre must become more a meeting and activity place access by bus or bike is more attractive withthe reduced traffic.       ,params: .pushMax WallisStrategic consultant John Jackson, who lives in Penarth, is in favour of partial pedestrianisation of Windsor Road on a trial basis.ldquoThis system works abroad, and works abroad in places where the weather isnrsquot always nice, he said. ldquoI think Penarth needs to be a more attractive environment post lockdown, and that would involve some sort of pedestrianisation.ldquoI think the idea to close off Windsor Road from Lower Glebe Street to the roundabout isnrsquot a bad one, and could instil some confidence for future changes.ldquoWhat I would question is whether the timing is right so soon after businesses have reopened.Five hundred people have responded to the town council survey so far.Cllr Nigel Humphrey - for St Augustines - said: ldquoPeople have been responding to the survey asit is a done deal, when in fact it is intended as part of a constructive dialogue about the future of our town centre."Gideon Calder of Gwyrddio Penarth Greeningsaid: ldquoFrom conversations with people, some are assuming that the current arrangement in the town centre ndash the bollards and one-way system ndash is the same thing as these alternative ideas about creating safer space."In fact these plans are quite dferent. Theyrsquore intended as a solutionto many of the problems which people are identying with things as they are.In a questionnaire circulated to traders by Penarth Business Group which waspassed onto the town council, of the  responders , . per cent said they against partof Windsor Road becoming a traffic free zone. . per cent said they were in favour of a one-way system being introduced to the town centre. . per cent said they were in favour of using wider roads for chevron parking.If you would like to find out more about the proposals visithttps:www.penarthtowncouncil.gov.uk news penarth-post-covid-your-views-on-our-town-centre .If you would like to make your views known but cannot access the survey online, you can call Penarth Town Council on   Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. Many staff took on dferent roles to normal, as some services were shut while other new ones were needed.Council workers organised covid- tests for both staff and residents arranged for businesses to be given breaks in paying rates and awarded almost pound million in grants to local businesses from the Welsh Government.Cllr Moore said: ldquoNone of us have sat back during this pandemic. It has been a dficult time and much work has gone on in the background. Itrsquos important to note the amount and complexity of the work our staff have carried out to keep the majority of our services in operation. Itrsquos a huge gratitude we have to give to our staff.ldquoThere has been an absolute willingness to experiment and take some measured risks, which have to be done under the circumstances. Projects have been driven through at an unusual pace.Cabinet member for social care and health, Cllr Ben Gray said: ldquoResponding to this emergency has been an incredibly complex task with many moving parts mdash one that isnrsquot over yet.ldquoStaff have continued to support those with profound disabilities. Carers are key workers who have been putting themselves in harmrsquos way to provide their most dedicated support for our most vulnerable. I canrsquot thank them enough.The next issues the council will face is how to reopen schools safely in September preparing town centres for non-essential shops opening and managing car parks now the five-mile travel rule has been lted.While schools were first shut and lessons began over the internet, some children struggled with a lack of technology at home. But the council provided laptops and internet to those in need.Cabinet member for education, Cllr Lis Burnett said: ldquoOur children werenrsquot left without IT connectivity. Our IT department provided  laptops or tablets to children, and  wi devices for children who didnrsquot have broadband.Builders are carrying on building new schools in the Vale, on socially distanced construction sites with contracts awarded locally.She said: ldquoWe havenrsquot stopped our st Century schools building programme, but delivered it in a very socially distanced way. August .The National Museum Cardf will open on Thursday, August  the National Waterfront Museum on Friday, August  the Big Pit National Coal Museum on Tuesday, September  the National Roman Legion Museum on Wednesday, September  and the National Wool Museum on Thursday, September .To ensure the visitor experience is as safe and enjoyable as possible, Amgueddfa Cymru has introduced a range of new measures.These include managing visitor numbers on site with pre-booking, physical distancing signage throughout the public spaces, one-way systems and enhanced hygiene regimes.Visitors can follow Amgueddfa Cymrursquos social media or website for details about how to book and what to expect on their visit www.museum.walesAmgueddfa Cymru has been supporting local business to source PPE and hygiene equipment during covid-.Sanitiser stations and gels have been sourced from Chemsol Cymru in Conwy whilst the PPE face visors for staff have been sourced from DMM Climbing in Llanberis.Director general of Amgueddfa Cymru, David Anderson said: ldquoWersquore all looking forward to welcoming our visitors back to our national museums."Although our buildings were closed, we have been open online over the last four months, providing learning resources for schools, art to field hospitals, and solace and inspiration for everyone."Museums play a key role in the health and wellbeing of people and communities and I hope everyone will come back out to visit us and support us.ldquoOur main priority remains that everyone stays safe and we will be following Welsh Government guidelines and continue to monitor the situation over the weeks ahead.ldquoWe are encouraging visitors to go to the website museum.wales to find out more about the new measures in place and also to enjoy the resources online and on our digital s.ldquoDuring the closures we have had a fantastic response to our lsquoCollecting Covidrsquo project asking the people of Wales to be part of the story by sharing their experiences and feelings of living in Wales during pandemic. This will form an important record for future generations.Amgueddfa Cymru ndash National Museum Wales is a family of seven museums and a collections centre, which are all free to enter thanks to the support of the Welsh Government.Together, it is home to the nationrsquos art, history and science collections, which will continue to grow so that they can be used and enjoyed by both present and future generations.Registered charity Amgueddfa Cymru is grateful for all support.The events and exhibitions programme is supported by players of the Peoplersquos Postcode Lottery.During this period a number of Amgueddfarsquos popular events can be enjoyed from home online.Find out more about the Amgueddfa Cymru digital food festival and Museum Sleepover: Dino Nights! for avoiding a second national lockdown.The Times reported the Prime Minister held a ldquowar game session with Chancellor Rishi Sunak on Wednesday to run through possible options for averting another nationwide lockdown that could stall any potential economic recovery.Mr Johnson was said to be considering asking the elderly to shield once again while also mulling lockdown-like conditions for London should there be a second wave of coronavirus infections, The Sundayand The Sunday Times said.Cabinet minister Mr Jenrick suggested the mooted increase in shielding was ldquonot something that is being actively considered.According to the , under proposals under discussion, a greater number of people would be asked to take part in the shielding programme, based on their age or particular risk factors that have been identied since March.It could even see those aged between  and  given ldquopersonalised risk ratings, said the Times, in a move that would add to the . million who were deemed most vulnerable and asked to shield from society during the spring peak.Mr Jenrick, when asked about whether new age-related measures were likely, told Times Radio: ldquoThis is just speculation.ldquoYou would expect the Government to be considering all of the range of options that might be available.ldquoThatrsquos not something that is being actively considered. vw,vw,px, px"The Prime Minister has reportedly asked for officials to draw up plans on how to avoid a lockdown like that seen in the spring He also said there was ldquono plan, as far as Irsquom aware to bring in travel controls and restrictions on where Londoners could stay as part of efforts to avoid any increased transmission rate in the capital from spreading to the rest of the country.It has been suggested that, should the R-rate escalate in the capital, the M would act as a travel border for London residents and people would be banned from staying the night at houses other than their own.It comes after Mr Johnson was forced to announce a slowdown of the lockdown easing last week, with planned relaxations for the leisure and beauty sectors delayed after a rise in Covid- cases was recorded, with prevalence in the community thought to be rising for the first time since May.Meanwhile, former England midfielder Paul Scholes has been accused of holding a party at his Oldham home to celebrate his sonrsquos st on the same day lockdown measures were reimposed across parts of Englandrsquos north-west.The Sun cited phone footage as showing revellers ignoring social distancing ldquoas they drank and danced at the seven-hour party, with the paper citing Tory MP Andrew Bridgen criticising Mr Scholes for ldquoreckless behaviour." data-title"HEALTH Coronavirus" data--holder"PA orbiting laboratory.The pair are expected to land in the ocean off the coast of Florida at around .pm UK time on Sunday.Mr Behnken and Mr Hurley made history on May  when they became the first people to launch into low-Earth orbit on a commercial spacecraft, built by SpaceX.Their mission, named Demo-, also marked the first time Nasa had launched astronauts from US soil in nine years.SpaceXrsquos astronaut carrier, the Crew Dragon, is expected to land in the water off Pensacola, western Florida.The US space agency said this location is far away from Hurricane Isaias, which is expected to hit the eastern part of the state.The last time astronauts made an ocean landing was on July  during an Apollo mission. vw,vw,px, px"Since then, they have always landed on terra firma, using Nasarsquos Space Shuttle or the Russian space agencyrsquos Soyuz capsules.If all goes to plan, the splashdown will usher in a new era for Nasa, which will have at least one commercial spacecraft ready to launch astronauts into space from US soil.The splashdown is the final step in the mission designed to test SpaceXrsquos human spaceflight system ndash including launch, docking, splashdown and recovery operations.In a post-launch conference back in May, Elon Musk ndash the founder of SpaceX ndash said he was not keen to ldquodeclare victory yet, emphasising that the ldquo can be more dangerous than the ascent.Mr Musk said at the time: ldquoWe need to bring them home safely and make sure that we are doing everything we can to minimise that risk of re-entry.Crew Dragonrsquos flight back to Earth with @AstroBehnken and @Astro_Doug remains on track targeting splashdown off the coast of Pensacola, Florida in the Gulf of Mexico at : p.m. EDT today https:t.co bJFjLCzWdKmdash SpaceXAugust , The Crew Dragon performed manoeuvres to lower the capsulersquos orbit and get it closer to the splashdown zone.The spacecraft is expected to perform another manoeuvre, known as de-orbit burn, which will place it on a trajectory for splashdown, travelling at about ,mph.On entering the Earthrsquos atmosphere, the Crew Dragon will face temperatures of around ,C as it deploys parachutes to slow its speed to around mph.At the point of splashdown, the capsule will be descending at around mph.The re-entry will create a communications blackout, caused by an envelope of hot air surrounding the capsule, which is expected to last about six minutes.GO Navigator makes its way to the primary splashdown zone off the coast of Pensacola, Florida for @AstroBehnken and @Astro_Dougs . #zwj####Listen in to learn how the recovery vessel will hoist @SpaceX #CrewDragon Endeavour with our astronauts inside # pic CFiVVAzCrmdash Johnson Space CenterAugust , A SpaceX recovery ship called Go Navigator ndash made up of spacecraft engineers, recovery experts and medical professionals ndash will be waiting to pull the capsule aboard and help the astronauts get out as they begin readjusting to gravity.The re-entry will mark the end of SpaceXrsquos human spaceflight demonstration mission.The aerospace companyrsquos first operational flight is expected to take place in September, where a second Crew Dragon spacecraft will carry four astronauts to the space station.The capsule that carried Mr Hurley and Mr Behnken into space will be refurbished and launched on SpaceXrsquos second operational crewed mission, Crew , due to take place early next year.Another aerospace company, Boeing, is also developing spacecraft to ferry astronauts to the space station, as part of Nasarsquos Commercial title: would you new wheelie box recycling council wants your opinion
story: Sadness as funeral of popular Co Armagh woman takes place todayPetrol bomb left at house in NINewsTraffic and TravelCrimeWeatherPoliticsBusinessEducationHealthPeopleRead ThisCoronavirusSportFootballOther SportWhats OnArts and EntertainmentThings To DoLestyleCarsHomes and GardensNewsWould you like a new Wheelie Box for recycling  Council wants your opinionCould Craigavon, Armagh and Banbridge be welcoming a new ‘Wheelie Box’ recycling stack By Carmel RobinsonThursday, th July , : pmUpdated Thursday, th July , : pm""It is all up to the people of the area to have their say as the Armagh, Banbridge and Craigavon put the option out for consultation.The Wheelie Box has three stacked boxes each for separate types of recycling material and is collected each week rather than each fortnight as the current green bins are.More things can be recycled in the Wheelie Boxes and, according to Bryson Recycling, they have a % greater recycling capacity than the current bins.Bryson Recycling Director, Eric Randall, pictured with team on a collection route.Box One is for paper, textiles, batteries and hand tools . Box Two is to recycle foil paper and boxes, food and drinks cans, aerosols and cartons such as milk containers and plastics also. Box Three is for cardboard, glass bottles and jars.Bryson Recycling saysadopted it could mean a jobs boost for the area as well as making recycling easier. The firm already has a link with the council, collecting recycling from homes in the Armagh area.Eric Randall, Director at Bryson Recycling says: “We are delighted that the Council is considering the Wheelie Box option. Collected weekly, the latest Wheelie Box model will offer % more capacity than a standard green recycling bin.This is an image of what can be put in the Wheelie Boxes.“Wheelie Boxes are a very much enhanced version of the kerbside boxes which are already in use in the Armagh area. The boxes have a lockable hinged lid and are integrated onto a trolley with wheels, which makes them secure and very easy to use and move.“As well as providing more space for recycling, Wheelie Boxes will also mean good news for local jobs because % of what we collect using this approach is recycled in Northern Ireland. This compares to typically around % using green bins.”Wheelie Boxes are not new, , households in Northern Ireland already use them.Bryson Recycling also pointed out that two firms based in the borough, Huhtamaki and Cherry Pipes, used recyclable materials.A number of dferent systems are currently in operation across the Borough and the consultation aims to introduce a single, streamlined recycling system from next year.Eric adds: “The Wheelie Box option means local households can increase the amount they recycle every week instead of fortnightly, protect local jobs, boost the economy and play an important role in creating a local, sustainable environment for all.”To voice your opinion, check out the link on the ABC Council website here https:www.armaghbanbridgecraigavon.gov.uk green-bin-or-wheelie-box-choose-which-to-use

title: autumn date set opening new south lake leisure centre
story: Manwho died suddenly on Sunday was father of a little girl‘He wore his great big heart openly on his sleeve’ mourners told at funeral of ‘legend’ Gary McConaghyNewsTraffic and TravelCrimeWeatherPoliticsBusinessEducationHealthPeopleRead ThisCoronavirusSportFootballOther SportWhats OnArts and EntertainmentThings To DoLestyleCarsHomes and GardensNewsPeopleAutumn date set for opening of new South Lake Leisure CentreA date has been set for the opening of the new south lake leisure centre in Craigavon with the multi-million-pound facility to open its doors on November .By The NewsroomTuesday, th July , : pmUpdated Tuesday, th July , : pm""The largest capital project to date undertaken by ABC Council, and among the largest in Northern Ireland, the new multi-use sports and leisure complex is described by the council as a major new flagship health and wellbeing destination.Work on the facility was halted by the coronavirus outbreak. Since ing to site Farrans, the contractor in charge of the build, has ensured the contract is completed ready for opening in the Autumn.Farrans has been spearheading the build since initial enabling works got under way early in , creating  jobs on site during construction as part of a project which has delivered at least £. million in direct wages to the local economy.Located at the south side of Craigavon’s balancing lake, the facility is a landmark venue for the area and is situated within a pre-existing network of walking and cycling paths covering around three miles. The council hopes the new leisure centre will welcome visitors from across the borough and beyond to its new -metre pool, a young children’s indoor leisure water feature, a ,m state-of-the-art gym, multiple studios, health and wellbeing suite, sensory room, eight-court sports halls, spin studio, soft play area and an on-site café.It also incorporates an outdoor water sports provision offering a wide range of water based activities including windsurfing, water skiing and paddle sports. The council says the scale of South Lake Leisure Centre has been future-proofed to meet the needs of a growing population and a raising demand from a range of leisure, amateur and professional sporting enthusiasts.Lord Mayor of Armagh City, Banbridge and Craigavon, Councillor Kevin Savage, sai: “With a confirmed opening date just  weeks away, I am delighted that this stunning new centre - which will have fabulous facilities for everyone in the borough to access and enjoy - is almost complete.“South Lake Leisure Centre provides a once-in-a-generation opportunity to transform and dramatically enhance the quality of health and leisure provision within the borough, providing community access for everyone to the best facilities available in the UK and Ireland.”As part of the preparations for the official opening of South Lake Leisure Centre, interim arrangements have been agreed for leisure facilities in Portadownand Brownlow . Cascades Leisure Complex will be open to the public for lane swimming only in August, remaining open until Saturday th October.Craigavon Leisure Centre will remain open to the public for gym only until Monday th October. Waves Leisure Complex will be closed to the public.When all these facilities, which are approaching the end of their al le close, leisure staff will begin their training at the new South Lake Leisure Centre building.""Most Popular." data-index"" data-s-event"gaEvent" data-s-ec"navigation" data-s-ea"most popular" data-s-el"" title"" class"sc-drMfKT fpqScQ"" alt"" layout"fill"" data-index"" data-s-event"gaEvent" data-s-ec"navigation" data-s-ea"most popular" title"" data-s-el"" class"sc-bGbJRg eOOfIS"Most Popular." data-index"" data-s-event"gaEvent" data-s-ec"navigation" data-s-ea"most popular" data-s-el"" title"" class"sc-drMfKT fpqScQ"" alt"" layout"fill"" data-index"" data-s-event"gaEvent" data-s-ec"navigation" data-s-ea"most popular" title"" data-s-el"" class"sc-bGbJRg eOOfIS"This website and its associated newspaper are members of Independent Press Standards Organisation Follow us onExploreNewsSportWhats OnLestyleMore from Portadown TimesAnnouncementsJobsPublic NoticesMust ReadBuy a PhotoDirectoryLocal GuideReader ShopUseful LinksContact UsAdvertise My BusinessAdvertise a JobPlace your AdSubscribeEventsArchiveReaders Charter" fill"#ea"©JPIMedia Publishing Ltd. ." target"_self" href"#" id"cookieSettings" class"sc-gxMtzJ sc-dfVpRl dLpuYr"Cookie SettingsTerms and ConditionsPrivacy policyNews you can trust since News" class"expand" role"button" tabindex""""" scale translate " points"  .  .
